content: this is dmg and in this video we will talk about how to make tree stumps with
a little bit of shade why do we need shade that will become evident well
hopefully will become evident otherwise
this is a variant of DM Scotties 2.5 D trees we're going to use these very thin
single layered cardboard sheets and this is really the lid of a pizza box you
know where I got that from so we're just going to use a marker to trace out some
treetop shapes so just I'm going to fit four on here small medium medium bigger
and large and we're going to cut those out so just cut them out into various
different blocks and then cut the around the actual markings themselves and then
we're going to take a toilet paper roll of course you know bog-standard
and mark out one inch little Mark's a long viitala roll so once you've done
that squish the toilet roll and cut to those 1-inch marks these are 2 and 1/2
centimeters if you are not using Imperial measurements and like me you
like the metric system so then just squish them back into shape as you
should and then we're going to grab some tin foil this is where it starts to get
a bit strange why on earth do we have tin foil let's just rip some strips of
tin foil we're going to need a few so get a few and then we're going to make
sure that they not super long so you want to be about 4 or 5 inches probably
4 inches long and then you're going to squish them into this long how how what
would you call it a line so just squish it all down and make a whole stack of
those you're going to need about three or four per actual tree stump then hot
glue to one side doesn't matter if it goes over we will use this for other
things so hot glue one side of the toilet paper roll and stick it to the as
much the center of each one of those things as possible
each one of those the treetop shapes that we measured then we're going to
grab those rolled up bits of tin foil and fold it over so there's a bit of a
loop and what glue about the roughly the same size as the piece that you have and
stick it down it is pretty good to have the loop sticking over the top of the
toilet roll there which is the top of the tree stump as I'm sure you have
guessed these are roots so we're just going to continue this process along and
you add three or four of these per tree stump and pinch them at the top so they
get thinner towards the top of the tree stump and you can pinch them along the
ends as well squish them down into the card stock and just be careful the hot
glue is hot so you don't want to burn yourself and when you're applying these
things you may want to wait for it to cure just a little bit so that it's not
as hot and just remember to pinch the top so I said we all apply three or four
of these and really this is giving us a texture as well as help to reinforce the
central trunk so once you've got there you just cut off the tops of those loops
that are going over the top of the cardboard the toilet roll and so that
makes it so nice and flush so they have it it's nice and clean and open and that
will become apparent as to why we're doing that and you see here one inch
gives you a nice at all place for a mini to hide depending on what game you're
playing Plus this will also help you with line-of-sight so the 2.5 d
obviously you could have a little bit of problem with line-of-sight and this
helps you to hide behind trees then get your hot glue gun and pull out from the
base from the top of the tree run it up and down rapidly to create a bark
texture on the outside of the toilet roll and also more so root structures
coming out of the base of the tree stump so quick up and down up and down motion
and pull out from the base of the tree about an inch in then runs black bonds
you'll see this is what it looks like so now we're going to apply some brown
paint apply it vertically so as you're applying the paint just stroke up
towards the top of the tree stump and continue that along all the roots and
all the texture but leave the base black so you can still see the black then
using white paint you want to do while it's still wet so while the brown is
still wet you just want to hit it a few times with the brush delicately with the
white paint you don't want to seriously mix the white paint in you you want it
to still be white when you're applying the paint and just go over each one of
these applying that white paint to all the textures that are there including
the ones on the base and you continue all the way around all of them then grab
some yellow paint and while it's still wet you don't even need to clean your
brush just put it into the yellow paint and then just flick it onto the piece so
less than you would have done with the white but just want to just give it just
a small little lick of paint that's all it really needs on some of the higher
areas then we're going to grab our sponge that we use for the pizza box
terrain where we went with green and this is the the sponge with the holes in
it then we're going to grab green paint and we're going to lightly put the green
paint on very very just just a little touch make sure you get a lot of it off
and then just stamp it on to the outside edges of that base so continue that with
all of them because the paint is wait some of the brown the yellow and the
white will probably mix with the green that is perfectly acceptable and
actually helps to make this look just that a little bit better so continue
that process all throughout now speaking of the pizza box strain here
is the driver of a bid and we're just placing the basis on there so now you
can see that obviously the green is coming through here as much darker once
it's dried you can see the colors and the texture creating the stump and minis
are much easier to move around when there's not so much vertical space in
obstructing them so that's how we make a whole stack of tree stumps ready to be
placed on your terrain in the next video we're actually going to make 3d trees
and we're gonna use the tree stump as the base haha me she is taking beam
